context: Harbor district — docks, shipping containers, wet roads, cargo ships

exchange.text: Watch the wet patches. Lost a buddy to hydroplaning last month.
On the road or the dock?
Does it matter? Wet ground kills either way.
They drift here at night. Cops don't bother — too many containers to hide behind.
Containers, forklifts, cranes... it's like a maze down here.
That's the point. You gotta earn your lines.
Saw a black car down here. No plates. No lights. Just... moving.
Moving where?
Everywhere. Nowhere. I don't know. It was like it wasn't even there.
Ship came in from Yokohama last night. Whole container of JDM parts. 'Mislabeled,' they said.
Another shift, another hundred crates of nothing.
At least we're not the ones racing through here at 2 AM.
Speak for yourself. I race through here at 2 AM AND work the shift.
Salt air eats paint. Eats rust. Eats everything. Harbor cars need twice the maintenance.
But Harbor drivers? Twice as tough. You learn to drive on these surfaces, you can drive anywhere.
They bring the imports through here. The real ones. Not the stuff at the dealership. The stuff that never sees a title.
Fog horn going off again. Third time tonight.
Adds to the ambience. Nothing like a harbor sprint with zero visibility.
That's not ambience. That's a warning.
You racers tear up the loading zone every weekend. You know I gotta fix that, right?
Consider it job security.
Job security is not cleaning tire marks off concrete at 6 AM.
The container alley run. Four turns, no room for error. Hit a box and you're done.
Done as in 'you lose' or done as in 'they find you next morning'?
Yes.
Crane operator up there's been paid off. He moves containers to clear the sprint lane after midnight.
Water's black tonight. Like oil.
It IS oil. Half the ships down here leak like a sieve.
Romantic.
Rain makes the docks a death trap. The surface turns to glass.
Best drift surface in the city though. If you don't mind the consequences.
Storm warning tonight. Perfect. The best races happen when God's trying to stop you.
Fog rolling in off the water. Can't see twenty feet.
That's when the Ghost shows up. Fog and Harbor go together like bad decisions and Tuesday nights.
Security guard just does his rounds and looks the other way. Everyone gets their cut down here.
Someone wrecked into the dry dock last week. Car sank in eight feet of water.
Driver make it out?
Driver swam out, walked home, and showed up to race the next night. Different car.
Late night at the docks hits different. Just the water, the engines, and the risk.
Poetry. From a guy who eats gas station sushi at 3 AM.
